awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity: Enhancing Undergraduate STEM Education by Enhancing Transfer Success
awd_abstract_narration:
The Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program (HSI Program) aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI Program will also generate new knowledge about how to achieve these aims.  This project will advance the aims of the HSI Program by increasing the number of students from community colleges who transfer to four-year STEM programs and by accelerating their baccalaureate degree completion.  This project is a collaboration between New York City College of Technology (City Tech) and six City University of New York (CUNY) community colleges, five of which are also HSIs.  The partners include the Borough of Manhattan Community College, Bronx Community College, Guttman Community College, Hostos Community College, Kingsborough Community College, and LaGuardia Community College.  The project aims to increase the number of students from the partnering community colleges who transfer into City Tech STEM programs and to accelerate baccalaureate degree completion by associate degree graduates.  To accomplish these aims, the project plans to strengthen transfer pathways between City Tech and the community college partners and to increase support for transfer students at City Tech. This project has the potential to increase the number of STEM students from underrepresented groups, which often begin pursuit of higher education at a community college. In addition, because CUNY is the largest urban public university system in the nation, innovations at CUNY can provide an example to the nation of creative approaches to improve student outcomes.

The goals of the project are to reduce barriers that inhibit transfer of students from community colleges to City Tech, and to maximize support for students who successfully transfer. To accomplish these goals, the project will create two programs.  First, using the existing CUNY Pathways articulation initiative as a model, the project will develop a STEM Transfer Collaborative to strengthen transfer pathways between City Tech and the collaborating community colleges.  Second, using the CUNY Accelerated Study in Associate Programs initiative as a model, the project will develop a Momentum to the Baccalaureate program to support junior and senior-level transfer students.  The project includes research on the impact on transfer student success of (1) collaboration between 2-year and 4-year colleges, including curricular and pedagogical alignment; (2) adoption of supports from an associate-degree support program to upper-level baccalaureate students; and (3) initial matriculation at a community college versus a baccalaureate institution.  The research methodologies and approaches in this study are informed by current and tested qualitative, quantitative, and mixed methods used in engineering education research. This project may increase the number of students, including those from underrepresented groups, earning baccalaureate degrees in career-focused, high-demand majors. In addition, it has the potential to create new knowledge on the critical national issue of how to expand opportunity and access to STEM baccalaureate programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: CUNY New York City College of Technology
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: CUNY New York City College of Technology

por.por_cntn:
New York City College of Technology (City Tech) utilized a five-year NSF HSI IUSE Track I: Building Capacity project (NSF 18-524) grant #1832457 to address Priority Area 1: Critical Transitions and Priority Area 3: Research on Broadening Participation in STEM.

As the City University of New York’s (CUNY’s) sole college of technology, and an urban, public, commuter, minority serving institution, City Tech's career-focused offerings in the engineering technologies and applied sciences provide unique opportunities to advance diversity and prepare graduates for high-needs careers in STEM. Participating bachelor’s programs in this effort included: Applied Chemistry, Computer Engineering Technology, Computer Systems Technology, Construction Engineering Technology, Data Science and Electrical Engineering Technology. Forty lower-level juniors were recruited each year of funding and received support for two academic years. The goal was 50% of each year's cohort transferring from one of our community college partners and 50% from transferring from our own associate degree programs  into our bachelor’s programs, after earning an associate degree.

City Tech is a comprehensive college, with a 2+2 structure in most majors – students can earn an associate degree enroute to their bachelor’s. This structure provided an opportunity to compare the academic success of a matched cohort of native associate degree graduates (internal transfer students )  and community college associate degree graduates (external transfer students) in the last two years of bachelor’s programs, in order to evaluate the effectiveness of pre-and post-transfer support designed to ensure student success.For community college transfer students, we created a STEM Transfer Collaborative (STC) with six CUNY community colleges - Borough of Manhattan Community College, Bronx Community College, Guttman Community College, Hostos Community College, Kingsborough Community College, and LaGuardia Community College - five of which are HSIs. We developed six new articulation agreements to maximize the transfer of contributory credits and held regular meetings with faculty to align curriculum and promote faculty professional development and adoption of evidence-based pedagogy at all 7 campuses. Additionally, City Tech faculty regularly reached out to potential transfer students at the community colleges for information sessions.To maximize support after transfer, our Momentum to the Baccalaureate (MB) initiative replicated some of the features of the highly successful ASAP model to suppo Supports included personalized advisement, early registration to assure the availability of needed courses and preferred times, and free monthly MetroCards, which allowed cost-free travel to the college, as an incentive for students to attend monthly meetings with their advisor, enroll full-time, ideally with an average of 15 credits per semester; participate in enriching programs at the college such as undergraduate research, maintain good academic standing and take advantage of campus support services.

Intellectual Merit: The Momentum to Baccalaureate (MB) support was shown to be effective in aiding City Tech students transitioning from two-year to four-year programs, exhibiting significant advantages in retention. Community college transfer students, upon successfully completing their first year with MB support, maintained comparable academic standards (GPA and credit accumulation) compared to “native” transfer students. However, there existed disparities in retention and graduation rates, indicating that the STEM Transfer Collaborative did not entirely overcome “transfer shock.” Four-semester graduation rates ranged between 23% to 37.5% for community college transfer students and 50% to 90% for the “native” transfer students.Both groups of students benefitted from Momentum to the Baccalaureate supports, consistently outperforming their matched peers who did not receive such support, in terms of retention, credit accumulation and GPA.

Broader Impacts: The students benefitting from this initiative represented a rich tapestry of diversity The self-reported ethnic/gender demographics of all cohorts were: Male: 75%; Female: 25%; Black: 19%; Hispanic: 42%; Asian: 23%; White: 4%; Unknown: 4%; External transfer students (42%); Native transfer students (58%).


Last Modified: 03/15/2024
Modified by: Pamela A Brown

New York City College of Technology (City Tech) utilized a five-year NSF HSI IUSE Track I: Building Capacity project (NSF 18-524) grant #1832457 to address Priority Area 1: Critical Transitions and Priority Area 3: Research on Broadening Participation in STEM.


As the City University of New Yorks (CUNYs) sole college of technology, and an urban, public, commuter, minority serving institution, City Tech's career-focused offerings in the engineering technologies and applied sciences provide unique opportunities to advance diversity and prepare graduates for high-needs careers in STEM. Participating bachelors programs in this effort included: Applied Chemistry, Computer Engineering Technology, Computer Systems Technology, Construction Engineering Technology, Data Science and Electrical Engineering Technology. Forty lower-level juniors were recruited each year of funding and received support for two academic years. The goal was 50% of each year's cohort transferring from one of our community college partners and 50% from transferring from our own associate degree programs into our bachelors programs, after earning an associate degree.


City Tech is a comprehensive college, with a 2+2 structure in most majors  students can earn an associate degree enroute to their bachelors. This structure provided an opportunity to compare the academic success of a matched cohort of native associate degree graduates (internal transfer students ) and community college associate degree graduates (external transfer students) in the last two years of bachelors programs, in order to evaluate the effectiveness of pre-and post-transfer support designed to ensure student success.For community college transfer students, we created a STEM Transfer Collaborative (STC) with six CUNY community colleges - Borough of Manhattan Community College, Bronx Community College, Guttman Community College, Hostos Community College, Kingsborough Community College, and LaGuardia Community College - five of which are HSIs.
